Textbooks will be distributed nationwide to all children; poorest children will benefit the most, since they currently lack textbooks almost entirely. Amount: US$132.5 million equivalent Terns: Repayable in 20 years, including a grace period of 5 years, at the Bank's standard variable interest rate. Project Objectives and Description: The five-year project would aim at improving the quality of basic education by addressing critical factors affecting both the supply of, and demand for, textbooks. This would be achieved through establishing government policies, regulations, procedures, and practices related to school books, and making textbooks available in classrooms in sufficient quantity and in a sustainable way. Specifically, the project would support: (a) provision of textbooks in all required subjects, for all children in primary (SD) and junior secondary (SLTP) schools, public and private, giving priority attention to poor children; (b) procurement of the SLTP textbooks from private publishers and Balai Pustaka, through a transparent and rigorous evaluation and approval process, with the objective of achieving a high quality in the books; (c) greater involvement at the provincial level, through implementing the procurement process for SLTP textbooks at the Kanwil level; (d) giving help to teachers in how to use the books better in the classroom; and (e) the promotion of reading, especially for children. Benefits: The ultimate benefit would be increased educational quality and improvements in literacy in schools providing basic education. The more immediate benefits would be quality enhancement of textbooks, the provision of about 157 million textbooks to SD students and 85 million to SLTP students, and a better use of textbooks in the schools.
 - U - Risks: The project would be exposed to some risks, but those seem manageable. First, within MOEC, current procedures and organizational units would be affected by the decentralization and privatization proposed under the project. However, most policy changes have already been introduced, and others seem fuily in line with the statements in the Government's new five-year development program. Second, the project's objective of providing good-quality textbooks, with fair competition among publishers at the provincial level, is complex and will require Kanwil expertise currently not available. The procurement procedures that will be followed for textbook procurement are expected to safeguard quality and competition, while also providing adequate control of the process at the Kanwil level.  1. BOOK AND READING ACTIWITIES IN INDONESIA A. BACKGROUND 1.1 Since Independence, Indonesia has carried out an intensive and active program of education improvement, particularly in expanding primary education. With the introduction of a special, additional presidential budget for primary education (INPRES SD) in 1973, the increasing number of primary schools and rising enrollments throughout the country have resulted in virtual universal primary education (see Annex 1). Today, about 27.4 million children are enrolled in about 137,000 public primary schools (Sekolah Dasar or SD), and a further 1.9 million children in about 10,000 private primary schools. The latter are government-supported, but managed privately, mainly by religious groups. A typical SD school consists of six classrooms, one for each grade, but increasingly, additional three-room blocks are being added for multi-purpose activities (e.g., principal's office, teachers' room, library, sick room). Each school has an allotment of at least nine teachers: a principal, six classroom teachers, and sports and religion teachers. Other models exist, especially in the remote areas, where multigrade schools are more common. 1.2 With universal primary education virtually achieved, the Government has now embarked on the accelerated expansion of enrollment for junior secondary schools (SLTP). The Government intends to extend, over the next 15 years, basic education to nine years. This entails a renewed program of building of schools and training of teachers to bring the total SLTP enrollment from about 6 million children at 20,000 schools now, to a total of about 13 million children by the year 2009. SLTP schools consist of three grades (grade 1 through 3), and typically will have 6 to 9 classrooms. Twelve subjects are taught by subject teachers. 1.3 The Government also intends to address quality throughout the education system. At the primary level, its fast expansion did result in quality trade-offs. Making sure that there were enough classrooms and teachers for all children has meant that not all buildings and teachers were of good quality. In addition, there has always been a shortage of educational materials. Budgets have been chronically inadequate. In recent years, Indonesia spent about 9.1 percent of its government budget for education purposes, of which about half for primary education. This compares with about 16 percent in Korea and the Philippines and about 20 percent in Singapore and Thailand (see Annex 2). Also, most of the primary education budget (about 85 percent) is used for teacher salaries. B. MAJORIssuEs 1.4 Quality Problems The shortage of resources has had an impact on the quality of education, which is still being felt today. Although there is a high initial enrollment,
 -2- there is also a retention problem: only 68 percent of primary school students complete six years in school, with wide variations from province to province (87 percent in Bali vs. 48 percent in West Kalimantan). Furthermore, transition rates to junior secondary schools are about 56 percent, and have been declining in the last few years. There is also evidence that children learn less in school than could be expected. Recent school assessment work in mathematics in Grades 5 and 6, carried out by Bank staff,' shows that tests on knowledge of material from the Grade 3 and 4 curriculum were variable, but low in many schools (for applied number problems, mean school scores ranged from 7 percent to 68 percent). 1.5 To correct these quality problems, improvements are now being carried out in a number of areas. A program has been started for upgrading pre-service primary teacher training, as well as strengthening in-service training. A program for improving secondary teacher training is also being prepared. Teacher salaries are being increased, and specia premiums are given to teachers who are being sent to teach in remote areas. Many primary schools are receiving additional classrooms, which can be used for a variety of purposes, and additional junior secondary schools are being constructed. For those areas where the basic school model is not appropriate, the Government is adjusting the model (e.g., multi-grade schools with fewer classrooms and teachers in low-population density areas). In addition, the INPRES SD progran, which started out primarily for school building purposes, is now increasingly being used for school maintenance and to purchase textbooks and supplementary reading and reference books for primary schools. 1.6 Reading Achievement. The achievement of reading and literacy is one of the main objectives to be accomplished during primary education. However, reading levels in the country are generally still very low, largely because of the lack of a receptive reading environment and reading culture. Indonesia traditionally does not have a strong reading culture, and emphasis has normally been placed on oral traditions, story telling, and visual drama. In addition, Bahasa Indonesia-the language of instruction-is not spoken as a first language by the majority of the population (only 15 percent of the population speak Bahasa Indonesia as their first language). The size and the diversity of the country, with large differences among regions and groups, make changes in reading behavior and the introduction of intervention programs slow and difficult. 1.7 Textbooks. Despite an official policy of free textbooks for all students, the availability of books to students-both in the school and at home-is very limited. Textbooks are published officially by the Government; several private publishers also publish textbooks, which are used in many schools. In recent years, the Government has been distributing free textbooks at a ratio of about one book per four students. Each year, some provinces are targeted, and then receive a much higher number of textbooks. During FY94/95, new curriculum books were provided for Grades 2 and 5 in SD schools and for SLTP Grade 2 in a 1:4 ratio. During FY95/96, books will be provided to all schools in poor villages (Desa Tertinggal, DT) schools in a 1:1 ratio. The distribution Somerset, Tony. Usually, the farther the schools are from the provincial capitals, the fewer books they receive. Warehouses have been built in all provinces to store the books, but their use is sporadic and not well managed. 1.8 Since there is such a shortage of government-produced textbooks, several private publishers have established large and thriving textbook publishing businesses. There are about 12 such textbook publishers, who, together, cover most of the country. Private publishers work largely through a sales force, outside of the bookstores, that market books to school principals and teachers. As a result, there are many more private, unofficial textbooks available in the schools than there are government textbooks. Quality-wise, some of the privately published textbooks are better than the government- produced books (better and more interesting treatment of the material, as well as better physical quality), and others are worse. In schools in more well-to-do areas, up to 70 percent of the children in the classroom may have their own textbooks, while in poorer areas none, or maybe only one or two, have a textbook. 1.9 Reading Books. To foster reading skills and behavior, reading and reference books play an important role, and are essential in broadening the vocabulary, creating the motivation to read, and providing information beyond the basics from textbooks. Establishing the habit to read should be done early in life, at the primary school level. Unfortunately, despite increasing book purchases by the Government, there is still a great shortage of accessible and interesting books. Separate rooms used as school libraries now exist in most secondary schools and in some primary schools, and there are book collections for general reading in virtually all schools. The books in most of these collections are old, poorly maintained, and of little interest; in many schools, large numbers of old textbooks are used as reading collections. 1.10 Publishing and Book Trade. Estimates of total book sales (excluding imports) are about 40 million books in 1991, with gross sales amounting to the equivalent of about US$55 million per year. This includes both textbooks and general books, and is less than US$1 per person, and about one book for every four to five people in the country, quite low by international standards (see Annex 5). Textbooks and other schoolbooks constitute about 70 percent of total book sales. With the exception of schoolbooks, the Government imposes very few regulations on publishers, printers, and booksellers. Business permits are easy to obtain, and there are no special restrictions on foreign investment in publishing and printing. As a result, barriers to entry for publishing and printing are low, and there are many players at every level, contributing to a competitive environment, and a book industry continuing to grow in size, technical competence, and sophistication. Controls and regulations on schoolbooks exist. Textbooks from private publishers for use as supplementary books in the schools must go through an elaborate approval mechanism that is highly centralized. Selection of reading books for use in schools is done in Jakarta, resulting in a select list of titles that are then distributed to all schools throughout the country. Although criteria for the selection processes have been established, actual book selection has not always been based on best quality.
 -4 - 1.11 Distribution and Access Problems. One of the main difficulties in making books available in Indonesia is the extreme geographic dispersion and the need to provide access across wide areas, many of which are difficult to reach. This has affected Government distribution of textbooks, which therefore have required specific distribution budgets at the local levels to allow for distribution to the school level. Particularly for Maluku and Irian Jaya provinces, the scale and magnitude of the distribution difficulties will require specific targeted action to resolve. It is also a problem for the private sector, which has to make a sufficient number of retail outlets available, which carry a large enough selection of books to be appealing to the local clientele. So far, retail outlets for books are largely concentrated in the cities and towns. Although the book industry is showing signs of initiative everywhere in finding alternative ways of bringing their books to the customers, there is still considerable scope for improvement. In recent years, the Government has contributed to building up the local book trade by decentralizing printing of its textbooks to printers at the provincial level and by requiring public libraries to buy for their collections from local bookshops. 1.12 Textbook Financing. Based on current Govenmment budgets and textbook purchases by parents from private publishers, an average of about 30 million textbooks annually have been produced and purchased in recent years. Total government expenditures for primary education are currently approximately US$70 per student per year.2 In addition, average parental expenditures are estimated at roughly US$35 per student (in student fees, uniforms and textbooks), although, obviously, there are wide differences in how much parents spend depending on income and their capacity to pay. Of the annual Government of Indonesia (GOI) primary school budget of Rp 3,000 billion, about Rp 75 billion (approximately US$1.20 per student per year) has been allocated for textbooks for FY94/95 and for FY95/96. In addition, parents spend an estimated Rp 90 billion per year on textbooks for all grade levels and school types, based on estimated sales figures of books sold currently by private publishers. To give all children in SD and SLTP (Grades 1-9) textbooks in all subjects would cost an estimated Rp 710 billion (Rp 400 billion for SD and Rp 310 billion for SLTP) during Repelita VI. The Government is planning to provide the necessary textbooks to cover all subjects, including teachers' guides. The GOI budget allowance for textbooks for the next five years would cover the provision of textbooks for SD, while Bank loan funds would be used to cover SLTP books. 2 Based on 1992/1993 GOT budget data.

Several government agencies are involved in furthering book distribution and reading in the country: (a) The National Book Development Council was established by Presidential Decree No. 5 of 1978 to help the Government in preparing book-related policies. It is responsible to the Minister of Education and Culture, with a membership covering the full range of government and private interests, including representatives of publishers, printers, distributors, writers, and translators. Over the past 16 years, it has made a host of recommendations for solving book-related problems, prepared drafts of laws and regulations, carried out research and studies, and cooperated with international agencies on seminars and training. This has contributed to the country's increased recognition of the importance of books as an essential input for the development process. (b) The Book Center acts as the Secretariat of the Council (with the Book Center Director as the Secretary), and was established by Presidential Decree No. 4 of 1978, and elaborated on in Ministerial Decree No. 0274/0/1987. It is an executive agency, reporting directly to the Minister of Education and Culture. It fails administratively under the Secretary General, and takes technical guidance from relevant Directorates-General of MOEC. It is responsible for book matters in MOEC, both textbooks and reading books, but has been mostly concerned with the production and distribution of textbooks.

It reprints, among others, the books produced by the Book Center and, in addition publishes its own textbooks and other books. It is estimated that Balai Pustaka covers approximately 5-7 percent of core- subject textbook needs. 1.14 School Book Evaluation. All books received or purchased by the schools need the endorsement of the Directorate-General of Primary and Secondary Education of MOEC. Books produced by the Book Center are not evaluated, but all privately published textbooks, reading books, and reference books for school use have to pass an evaluation process, managed by the Directorate of Education Facilities of the Directorate- General, to be put on the "list of school books published by private publishers which have been legalized". Books are evaluated on the basis of (a) contents, (b) national security, (c) language, and (d) graphics, and the list of approved books is then circulated to the regions. However, the evaluation process is cumbersome, time-consuming, and not always the best books are selected. 1.15 Reading Book Evaluation and Distribution. Reading books (buku bacaan) are intended for school libraries, and can be assigned by teachers to students as extra reading. Since 1973, part of the INPRES SD (special budget, targeted for primary schools) budget (recently about Rp 37 billion) has been used for the purchase of reading and reference books in primary schools. Each year, depending on the budget, a list of titles is selected by central government officials, managed by the Directorate of Education Facilities. The number of titles has been as high as 120 (in 1992), but is usually less. In principle, one copy of each selected title is sent to each primary school in the country. In practice, however, far fewer copies are printed and distributed. Also, the same distribution problems that plague the Book Center's textbooks are evident with these INPRES SD books. As a result of the selection and distribution problems, much of the substantial investment in reading books is wasted. Recently, the reading book selection process has been much improved; in addition to the existing evaluation and selection procedures, proposed reading books are read by children in three provinces, whose evaluation also contributes to the overall score.

PREVIOUS INVOLVEMENT 2.1 Since the early 1970s, the Government has undertaken an ambitious program of formal and non-formal education and training development. The Bank Group has supported 31 education and training projects (US$1,860 million total) in the sector, of which 20 projects (USS1,263 million total) were or are implemented through MOEC (see Annex 4). 2.2 The Bank supported two textbook development projects in Indonesia from 1973 to 1988 [Third Education Project (Cr. 387-IND) and Second Textbook Project (Ln. 2102- IND)]. Both projects had as their central objective to improve the availability and quality of textbooks. The Third Education Project-the first Bank operation anywhere to deal with the problem of inadequate and inappropriate textbooks-produced about 300 million textbooks and teacher guides, while its successor produced an additional 150 million. While this represented a great improvement over the previous, textbook-starved era, the projects produced textbooks whose physical quality and content was less than adequate. In addition, the lack of storage facilities along the distribution chain meant losses and wear and tear even before the books reached the classrooms. The Book Center, with a network of almost 300 warehouses and depots to assist in the large-scale distribution of textbooks from one central agency, was created to address these problems. 2.3 The Bank is also supporting several ongoing and proposed projects aimed at quality improvement at the basic education level. The Primary Education Quality Improvement Project (Ln. 3448-IND) provides a package of quality improvements in schools in six pilot provinces; it aims to improve the local management of primary schools; supports in-service training for principals, teachers, and tutors; and fosters a better school environment through greater community participation, educational materials, and teacher motivation. Simultaneously, the Primary School Teacher Development Project (Ln. 3496- IND) focuses on pre-service training of teachers and a better system of teacher supply, allocation, and distribution. In addition, the Second Secondary Education and Management Project (Ln. 3158-IND), as well as future planned Secondary Education Development Projects, address requirements and weaknesses at the secondary level. These projects combined represent an extensive and intensive approach on the part of the Government and the Bank to deal with the quality weaknesses that are currently evident in basic education. 2.4 The Government now plans to specifically address the availability and use of textbooks in basic education schools, as one of the major educational inputs into education. In the delivery of a quality basic education system, textbooks are essential. Creating a better workforce and improving the quality of basic education means not only
 - - improving the teachers, but providing them also with the necessary tools to carry out teaching. Putting books in the schools is one of the most cost-effective ways of improving education quality. B. LESSONS LEARNED 2.5 Much experience has been gained from earlier Bank-assisted projects and sector work in basic education in general and textbook development in particular. The proposed project reflects the lessons learned from the Project Performance Audit Report Ion the previous two textbook projects (both with a satisfactory rating), the Bank's "Indonesia - Basic Education Study"' and recent informal sector work carried out by Bank staff in Indonesia. It also reflects Bank experience with education and textbook projects elsewhere in the world, as well as with current research on the importance of reading. The main lessons are: (a) Financing of Textbooks. The Government must ensure that children in all schools in the country have textbooks available to them. A comparison with recent activities in textbook provision in other developing countries is useful. Annex 3 provides an overview of recent World Bank-assisted projects for textbook support in nine countries. As can be seen from the table, a range of activities and policies is evident. While some countries provide free textbooks for all (Brazil in some provinces, Chile, Romania and the Philippines), others target textbooks to poor areas or students, with cost-recovery from richer parents in some cases (China, and Venezuela). In India (Province of Uttar Pradesh), textbook costs have been kept vezy low and all parents are expected to purchase for their children. In all these cases, however, the objective is and has been to ensure that adequate numbers of textbooks are available in the schools, and that a continuing supply is possible on a sustainable basis. (b) Textbook Procurement and Distribution. Bank experience with textbook projects throughout the world shows that there are frequent problems with the currently used methods of procurement. Most importantly, the distribution mechanisms down to the school level are frequently deficient or not enough taken into account in the procurement process. Unless distribution down to the school is made an integral part of the procurement contract, books often remain in warehouses and are not received in the schools. In the project, distribution to the school level will be given close attention, and will be carried out as a part of the procurement contract. 3 OED Report No. 10678, Apri 15, 1992. 4 Report No. 7841-IND, Deember 22, 1989.

In Indonesia, the regulatory laissez-faire for general books is matched with a restrictive framework for school books. There are large time lags in getting school books approved, and these drive up publishers' costs unnecessarily. In addition, the annual large-scale government purchasing of reading books under the Inpres SD budget has a distorting effect on the book industry. Therefore, a major emphasis on increasing the production and improving the quality of books-both textbooks and general reading books for school use-should be accompanied by streamlined procedures, allowing for fair and equitable competition. (d) Relative Roles of Government and Private Sector. During the past 20 years, the Government has played a major role in the provision of textbooks, and the establishment of the Book Center institutionalized the Government's position. Nevertheless, budgetary support has been limited, especially after the closing of the two Bank-supported projects. As a result, the private sector has tried to fill the gap, and now produces 80 percent of all textbooks in the country. There is a need to clarify this relationship between the Government and private publishers, and to establish what each partner will be responsible for. It seems that the Book Center should shift from textbook production to becoming a policy and quality control body while production and distribution should be largely handled by the private sector. It is also expected that the Book Center will support textbook evaluation for use in schools. Greater attention on the part of Government to its role in quality control should result in better- quality books being introduced in the schools. C. BANK STRATEGY 2.6 The Bank's Basic Education Study5 concluded that the quality of education in most of the country's primary and secondary schools was deficient, and this is basically still the case. The study recommended that more resources should be given to schools, especially to schools where parents are unable to contribute. Improvements in teacher competence and streamlining of the budget process were also identified as needing attention. Based on this study, and on the Government's priorities as laid down in its five-year development plans, recent Bank strategy in basic education has been to address quality improvements through a multi-pronged approach, of which this project would be a critical element.  - 10- 2.7 The Book and Reading Development Project supports the Bank's 1995 CAS for Indonesia, which was presented to the Board on March 21, 1995. The CAS places emphasis on the importance of quality in education, especially of basic education. Poor children will be ensured of having the necessary educational materials they cannot afford. The Project also supports regional development, by placing textbook purchasing decsion- making in the hands of the provinces. The Bank's comparative advantage in textbook provision lies in its systematic overview and support of basic education, its complementarity with ongoing and future projects in primary and secondary education- including previous textbook projects-and its global expertise with textbook production and distribution. 2.8 The main goals of basic education are to develop, at the primary level, basic numeracy and literacy skills, as well as the ability to apply basic skills to new problems. Children who have gone to school for six years should have basic literacy; be able to transfer their knowledge to related problem solving; and know basic arithmetic operations. If these goals are not accomplished during the primary education process, it compromises the entire education system, and produces students who are poorly prepared for secondary and tertiary level education. The acquisition of literacy requires children who not only can read-become literate-but will read-develop a reading habit. Instructional materials are key elements in this process. They are also the main instruments used by teachers in delivering the curriculum. Good textbooks help students to learn, in addition to the time spent in the classroom. It is, therefore, essential that sufficient textbooks of good quality are available in all classrooms. In addition, and equally important, children should have access to reading and general reference books, including dictionaries and atlases. At the secondary school level, textbooks are equally important, to deliver a more complex curriculum, and with subject matter that may require repeated coverage and individual study by the students. 2.9 A recent comprehensive coverage of this subject in "Improving Primary Education in Developing Countries" by Lockheed and Verspoor, states explicitly that, because textbooks typically deliver the curriculum, they are regarded as the single most important instructional material. Nothing has ever replaced the printed word as the key element in the educational process and, as a result, textbooks are central to schooling at all levels. Sufficient availability of textbooks can ensure that instructional time is not wasted. Without them, teachers and students copy text on and off blackboards. Over the past decade, researchers have documented the consistently positive effect of availability of textbooks and other instructional materials on student achievement in developing countries. For example, in Nicaragua students in classes randomly assigned to receive textbooks scored significantly higher, by about one-third of a standard deviation, on a test of mathematics achievement than students in classes with no supplementary materials. In the Philippines, first and second grade children were supplied with textbooks under two different conditions: a student to textbook ratio of 2:1 and a student to textbook ratio of 1:1. A comparison group was drawn from students in school the previous year when the ratio of students to textbooks was 10:1. The effect of having textbooks was substantial, with students in both textbook conditions scoring about one-third of a standard deviation higher on tests of science, mathematics and Filipino than the comparison group. In Brazil,
 - 11 - the effects on student learning of adding various "school quality" elements to poor rural schools were studied over a five-year period 1981-1985; one element was textbooks. Second and fourth grade students in schools receiving textbooks scored significantly higher on tests of mathematics and Portuguese than students in schools lackig textbooks. More recent research in Northeast Brazil confirms the crucial imporance of textbooks for education performance.

In particular, the project would be expected to contribute to improving the production and distribution of more and better quality textbooks, their availability in the classrooms, and their use by teachers in the curriculum. These supply and demand objectives would be achieved by assisting in the implementation of a textbook provision and distribution system to all elementary and junior secondary school children on a sustainable basis; giving help to teachers in how to use the books better in the classroom; and motivate and promote reading habits among children. The ulimate benefit would be increased educational quality and improvements in literacy in schools. The immediate benefits would be quality enhancement of text books, increased access to textbooks by all students, and stronger private sector book production in general and of school books in particular. The project would provide a total of 250 million textbooks, and will result in a major revision of the school book production and distribution system. The latter alone is already of major benefit to the more rapid development of the private book industry. 5.2 Investment in textbooks in other countries has shown, through a substantial research body, that improvements in quality are substantial, while textbooks generally represent only a small proportion of the education budget (in Indonesia, 4 percent of the primary education budget). Overall, investments in primary and secondary education achieve high social rates of return, by comparison to other education inputs. The continuing provision of textbooks will have a substantial quality benefit, at a relatively low cost. Other benefits are the increase in private sector involvement and the purchase of books in large series, which should result in a reduction in book prices, estimated at 20 percent. 5.3 Risks. The project would be exposed to some risks, but those seem manageable. (a) There is strong Government commitment on the policy to provide complete coverage of textbooks to all students, and to allocate sufficient budget to become fully sustainable after project completion. The budget amount currently allocated for SD school construction would be partly transferred to allow procurement of books, ensuring long-term sustainability. (b) Procurement procedures and involvement from the private sector will require a great deal of adjustment, while improving textbook quality. The procedures that will be followed provide for adequate quality control at the national level, through the National Evaluation and Approval Committee. Sufficient competition in the bidding process will also result in lower prices for the textbooks. (c) The decentralization of procurement to the provincial level will require the acquisition of skdlls and expertise in the Kanwil that currently may not exist or be inadequate.  -35- ANNEX 5 INDONESIA BOOK AND READING DEVELOPMENT PROJECT BooK INDUSRY 1. The Market. The salient feature of the book industry in Indonesia is the limited extent of the market. A general-book publisher will be satisfied if its sales are 3,000 copies a year for the average title on its list. A book is considered a best seller if it sells more than about 10,000 copies a year. One of the principal reasons for the limited number of book sales lies with weak demand. For many reasons, the number of Indonesians that would like to buy books, at present prices, is relatively small. The reading public for books by mainstream publishers is restricted mainly to a section of the middle- and upper-income groups. 2. Regulatory Environment. With the exception of schoolbooks, the Government imposes very few regulations on publishers, distributors, and printers. Business permits and industxy permits are easy to obtain. Censorship does not appear to be a great concern to publishers. There are no special restrictions on foreign investment in the publishing or printing businesses. Therefore, the only barrier to entry into the publishing business is the need for a relatively small amount of capital, mainly working capital. 3. Publishing. According to IKAPI (the Indonesian Publishers' Association), 7,229 new titles were published in 1991, compared with 1,421 in 1981-an average annual compound growth rate of 18 percent Again according to IKAPL 40 million books were produced in 1991, compared with 21 million in 1981-an average annual compound growth rate of 7 percent. Assuming an average book price of Rp 2,900 (70 percent schoolbooks at Rp 2,000 and 30 percent general books at Rp 5,000), total gross sales revenue might be about Rp 116 billion in 1991. The 1992 book list from EKAPI lists 273 publishers that are IKAPI members and an additional 181 nonmembers. Other data for 1991 showed a total of 254 publishers in Indonesia, 145 of which were in Jakarta and 85 in the rest of Java, leaving only 24 outside Java. Data on industiy concentration are difficult to obtain. Incomplete data from IKAPI suggest that the top four publishers account for no more than 10 percent of the total number of book copies sold. It is generally believed in the trade that schoolbook publishers are more highly concentrated. 4. Noteworthy features of the Indonesian publishing industry include a lack of skilled labor in many areas of the business: editorial work, translation, management, marketing. These deficiencies are not unique to the publishing industry, but the lack of market knowledge is more unique. Very little formal market research is carried out to learn who readers are and what they want. Publishers feel that it is too expensive to conduct market surveys, and they question their value. Instead, good publishers study market trends and carry out informal observations at bookstores to see who is reading and buying different
 - 36 - ANNEX S kinds of books. There is a tendency to focus attention on the government as customer rather than on the ultimate consumer of books. Pressure groups lobby to get lucrative government contracts, since there are greater profits to be realized this way than by taking the trouble to size up and cater to the market of anonymous consumers. Other characteristics of the publishing industry that may affect its ability to respond quickly to changing demand are the following: * A common opinion is that it is difficult to find good local authors because of the low level of remuneration. Royalties run 5-15 percent of the list price, which is normal in the trade, but since the expected production quantity is low (3,000 copies sold in two years would not be unusual), the incentive may not be enough to entice many talented writers. This is one of several vicious circles found in the Indonesian publishing business. Many publishers appear to set their prices based on untested assumptions and do not give enough attention to more sophisticated pricing strategies. * Most publishers pay little attention to advertising and promotion as a way to generate sales. They feel they cannot afford it-an example of another vicious circle. 5. The unauthorized reproduction of locally produced books (pirating) is considered a serious problem by publishers, but its true extent is not known. While some best-selling novels are pirated, most affected seem to be those books with a steady long-term demand, such as dictionaries and other reference books; these books present the least risk for the pirate. Textbooks are also prime targets. Investigation of the offense and enforcement of the copyright law by government authorities are weak, though recently, more attention has been given to the issue. 6. Printers. It is difficult to know how many book printers there are. Lists of printers are of little use, since many are commercial printers, dealing in forms, stationery, product packaging, etc. Many printers exist in name only, having been set up to profit from various government contracts. They then subcontract out the work to genuine print shops. There are a great number of book printers in the Jakarta area, entry is easy, and competition is intense. Little investment is needed to start up a small print shop; many exist in the back rooms of people's homes. There is great variation in size and competence, and, according to reports, many printers lack technical and managerial skills. The greatest potential constraint for printers in general is paper supply, but Jakarta printers have no complaints on this count at the present time. Printers keep very little paper in stock, as they can obtain it quickly from their distributors. 7. Distribution and Independent Wholesalers/Distributors. Some publishers complain about the difficulties of distributing their books, but the real problem is often that their books will not sell or that they know little about marketing. Distribution is a complex problem in the book business because of the highly differentiated nature of the product: each of many bookstores needs to have the products of many publishers. The problem is being addressed in a number of ways in Indonesia, and it appears that the private sector is capable
 -37- ANNEX5 of developing new solutions to meet the evolving demand of publishers. Publishers generally deal with the large bookstores (e.g., the chains) directly, and then perhaps use independent distributors to reach the smaller stores. Distribution by publishers is handled routinely. There is very little training of sales representatives; little promotion is carried out; it is usually expected that the book will sell itself to even the smaller retail outlets. 8. It is estimated that there are about 10 important distributors in the Jakarta area and about 50 in Indonesia as a whole. Most distributors receive the greater part of their revenue from the distribution of schoolbooks. There are a number of specialized distributors, e.g., for dictionaries and other reference books, medical books, etc. Independent distributors are performing a useful service in the book business: They cut down on administrative and shipping costs by consolidating orders and shipments. They give the same trade discount to bookstores regardless of how many books are purchased from a single publisher, whereas the small bookstore would often receive a lower rate on a small order placed directly with the publisher. They can help deal with the problem of uncollectible accounts, because bargaining power is increased when many publishers' accounts are consolidated. 9. Shipping. Shipping costs account for 1-2 percent of a book's list price on average. Many shipping methods are used: post office, air freight, private shipping agents, and freight forwarders. Private shipping agents and forwarders, who give speedy, reliable, door-to-door service, are preferred for large shipments-say, for more than five kilograms (usually 15-30 books). Within Java, costs are very low. For most of the distant locations in Indonesia, shipping costs by private shipping agents amount to no more than 5 percent of the retail value. Surface parcel post generally cannot compete because of the long delivery time, though it has the advantage of being inexpensive and capable of reaching more parts of the country than the private-sector services. The high cost of air parcel post becomes burdensome for direct mail sales of just a few books, unless their value is relatively high. 10. Retailers. According to IKAPI (1992 book list), there are 2,895 bookstores in Indonesia, 346 in Jakarta and 1,381 in the rest of Java. It is not known for how many of these the major activity is book selling or how many have more than a tiny range of titles in stock. A recurring opinion is that most Indonesian bookstores lack management skills, marketing strategies, and well-trained staff who can lead people to the books they might want. 11. National and local chains together probably account for more than half of all book sales from bookstores. The chains are competitive and will take potentially marketable books from any publisher, apparently without discrimination. Several companies are involved in door-to-door sales of encyclopedias and similar books. Some publishers have tried mail-order sales without much success: the response rate is low. One successful
 -38 - ANNEX S company, however, has a list of about 75,000 confirmed buyers throughout Indonesia, even outside major towns, where well-supplied bookstores are scarce. 12. Book Imports. There is no import duty on book imports. But unofficial fees may work out to 4-8 percent of the sales price of the books. The import process is usually fairly rapid, taking about two weeks. 13. Informal Sector: Cheap ("Pasar") Books. Alongside the conventional book industiy exists another, operating through different channels, and catering to a different segment of the market. In Indonesia, true mass-market books are sold in the traditional bazaars (pasar) and by street vendors. There, cheap romance and horror novels sell for Rp 1,000, compared with some Rp 3,000 for a bookstore novel. The language and style are simple and the physical quality of the books is poor. Very little appears to be known in a systematic way about this informal segment of the industry, which is unhindered by government regulation or controls. Readers appear to come mainly from segments of the population below the middle-income groups, many perhaps with only a primary school education. 14. Exports of Books. Exports of books are insignificant at the present time, amounting to only US$594,000 in 1992. But several printers believe that, if paper costs could be reduced, Indonesia could offer competitive prices for printing jobs done for foreign publishers. Export printing jobs are undertaken from time to time-often, it appears, with Singapore publishers. 15. The School Textbook Industry. The production of school textbooks is a very different business from the production of ordinary books for several reasons: first, the Government itself plays a direct role in producing these books; second, school textbooks published by the private sector must first be approved by the Government; third, the particular nature of demand for the books is shaped by the school curricula and national exams developed by the government. There are three primary actors in the production of textbooks for primary and secondary schools. (1) The Book Center (Pusbuk) is the unit within the Department of Education and Culture (MOEC) responsible for the production and distribution of free textbooks. (2) Perum Balai Pustaka, a state-owned enterprise, is the printing house of MOEC. It reprints the books produced by the Book Center and, in addition, publishes its own textbooks and other books. (3) Private publishers are permitted to produce and sell school textbooks so long as they have been approved by MOEC, in particular the Directorate of Educational Facilities (Direktorat Sarana Pendidikan). (a) Book Center. The Book Center produces main textbooks for certain subjects. (b) Balai Pustaka. Balai Pustaka reprints Book Center book, and sells them as if it were a private publishers. Distribution is mainly carried out by private distributors. A rough estimate suggests that Balai Pustaka is covering 5-7 percent of core-subject textbook needs. The figures make it clear either that demand for "required" books is lacking or that Balai Pustaka is not able to supply the number of books demanded. Balai Pustaka also develops
 - 39 - ANNEX 5 supplementary texts entirely on its own, as if it were a private publisher. The approval process is the same as for supplementary texts published by private publishers. Balai Pustaka sometimes issues a supplementary text for the same course for which it is reprinting a required text. (c) Private Sector. Private publishers are free to produce and distribute school textbooks so long as the books have been approved by the Directorate of Educational Facilities in MOEC. The basic procedure involves an evaluation and clearance by the Directorate of Educational Facilities of the text submitted by a private publisher. The books must be in complete, ready-to-sell form (no proofs accepted). An evaluation team looks at four aspects: contents, national security and state philosophy, language, design and physical quality. If the book submitted by the private publishers is for one of the designated courses, it is by definition considered a "supplementary text," since "main texts" for these courses are a government monopoly, produced by the Book Center. In practice, the contents may be exactly like that of a main text, and the book may be used as a main text by the school or teacher. Once the book is approved, the private publisher carries out the rest of the process without further government supervision or regulation. Promotion takes place at the levels of the provincial MOEC office and school. Private publishers like to sell direct to schools and teachers. 16. Reading/Library Books. Reading/library books (buku bacaan) are intended for school libraries. In the "Inpres SD" program, directed at primary school libraries, the Directorate of Educational Facilities purchases from private publishers. Some book titles are specifically developed by publishers with a view to selling them to the Inpres SD program; many of these books are of little interest to children and would generate negligible sales if an attempt were made to sell them in bookstores. However, the result of the Inpres SD program can be a boon to a private publisher, who might otherwise be selling only 2,000- 4,000 copies of the book through normal channels. Books were purchased from 151 publishers in 1992/93. This program may have a considerable impact on aggregate demand for books. Based on IKAPI figures for total book production during the period 1988-91, 15 percent of all books produced were purchased through the Inpres SD program. 17. The Book Center is responsible for library books at the high school level. The size of the program is much smaller than the Inpres SD program, however. In contrast to the SD program, only a small percentage of the books are selected and purchased directly by the Book Center; most are purchased by the provincial MOEC offices at their own discretion, usually from local bookstores. 18. The Price of Books. An analysis of the costs of producing and selling a typical book is useful for estimating what the impact on the average price would be if publishers sold more of each title, instead of the 1,000-4,000 that is said to be typical now. The price decrease comes about because the fixed costs involved in the production of each title can be spread over a larger number of copies. Increasing the number of copies sold would have a considerable impact on the average price. For a publisher now selling in the range of 3,000-
 -40 - ANNEX 5 6,000 copies, doubling production would permit a decrease of 25-30 percent in the price of its books. 19. Paper is relatively expensive, but almost all the paper used in book production in Indonesia is now produced domestically; only special papers are sometimes imported. The quality of the best local paper is quite good, though there is considerable variability among producers. The tariffs on ordinary printing paper (25 percent) and newsprint (40 percent) are higher than needed, but the likely impact on the price of a book is limited; prices would come down by no more than 6 percent if tariffs were reduced to zero. 20. Publishers and distributors with annual sales over Rp 120 million and retailers (e.g., bookstores) with sales over Rp 1 billion must register and pay VAT of 10 percent on the sale of books. However, the Govermnent has made the decision to declare certain kinds of books nontaxable: (a) books used by schools, universities, etc., in support of the curriculum; and (b) sacred scriptures and other educational religious books. Publishers must submit their requests for nontaxable status through IEAPI. IKAPI then forwards the books to the appropriate department (Education or Religion) for its recommendation. The list is then sent to the Department of Finance for final approval. The entire process is said to take three to four months. IKAPI estimates that about 90 percent of all titles in print have been declared nontaxable.

The procurement of textbooks and the related teachers' guides under the project would consist of purchase of all necessary textbooks and teachers' guides at a 1:1 book:student ratio for all subjects in all SLTP schools (procurement of books for SD schools would continue under sole GOI funding and procedures). (b) Procurement will be carried out at the provincial level by Kanwils, which will select for tendering a minimum of three approved series for each subject. (c) For series from the private sector, bids will be accepted from publishers (i.e., those holding the copyright/publishing rights to the series ) or booksellers/distributors working in association with the copyright holders. For series from Balai Pustaka, in which publishing rights are deemed to be non-proprietary, bids may be accepted from any qualified company (publisher, printer, bookseller, etc.) if successful such a bidder will enter into a license agreement with Balai Pustaka. All bidders will be required to post-qualifSy in conjunction with the bid itself. (d) MOEC will review all selections made before contracts are awarded. Further details on the procedures follow.  -51- ANNEX7 The Committee should include relevant government officials from different government departments, to evaluate the legal, national, security, and book quality aspects; it should also include principals, teachers and IKIP staff. Titles must form a series comprising work for all three grades of SLTP, preferably (but not necessarily) in the format of one pupils' book and teachers' guide per grade (or one teachers' guide per grade where no pupils' books are required). Titles can be submitted by either private publishers (local or foreign) or Balai Pustaka for evaluation by the Committee. Titles can be submitted either as ready printed books or as unpublished camera-ready copy (CRC) with a printed sample chapter. Clear and specific pedagogical and technical criteria will be established on the minimum quality required (with standards set sufficiently high to guarantee good pedagogical quality and technical durability); and a merit point system will be developed to reflect the relative weight that should be attached to each pedagogical criterion in order to enable quality comparisons. The criteria developed for the Book and Reading Development Project proposal can be used as a basis for further development. A minimum of three approved titles will be required for each grade before tendering can begin. 5. For series published by Balai Pustaka, in which copyright is non-proprietary, bids will be accepted from any qualified supplier (whether printer, distributor or other). Textbook Evaluation Criteria Textbook Any textbook should present correct scientific, technical and other facts using an appropriate and acceptable method of presentation, well integrated and clear illustrations and layout, and ethically acceptable text. Textbook writer A textbook writer (either an individual or a team) must have expertise and teaching experience in the subject matter and creative skills for the planning and generation of manuscripts. Criteria for evaluation T The evaluation should consider at least five aspects of any textbook, i.e., content, methodology, language, security and graphical presentation. Content aspect The content aspects of the book should consider: * The starting level of knowledge of its readers. X Presentation of the material should be consistent with similar disciplines for the same educational level. * Coverage of the subject matter must be relevant to the scope and sequencing of material as expressed in the existing curriculum * Information should be linked to suitable questions (with and without given answers) and exercises designed to assist the learning process and test pupil progress. * Information taken from other sources should be acknowledge. * For later grades, contents should be indexed where appropriate. Methodology aspect * The approach used in the book should reflect the approach suggested by the curriculum (e.g., pupil-centered, learning by discovery for science). * Scope and sequencing should be logically planned, starting with content familiar to the pupil, and followed by new, complex and abstract subjects. * There should be a clear and consistent hierarchy of presentation (i.e., Chapter, Subchapter etc., headings).
 -55- ANNEX 7 Language aspect * The language used in the book should be relevant to the users, and easily understood according to their language abilities in terms of O vocabulary (special terminology, wording, spelling) 0 sentence structure 0 paragraphing Security aspect Textbooks should: * Be in line with and not contradictory to Pancasila, UUD-1945, and MPR Decisions. * Be in line with and not contradictory to Government Policies. * Not lead to the disunity of the Nation. * Not be contradictory to the Laws, existing Regulations and Ethics. * Not create conflicts between Religions, Races, Tribes or local cultures and traditions. Graphical Presentation Specifications for graphical presentation must be considered as a single aspect in combination with the content being presented. For example, various combinations of typeface, font size, line length, margin depths, etc. may be more or less suitable for different kinds of material presentation and page format. The specifications given below are thus intended only as general guidelines and examples, and more detailed specifications will be provided in the bidding documents for each title. The following aspects should be considered in book design and layout: * Illustrations (and relevant captions) should support the text, be clear and easily understood. * Use of color should be relevant to needs (for economy purposes, screened 2- color printing is deemed more efficient than spot 4-color). * Spatial relationships between text and illustrations should be consistent. * Typefaces and font sizes should be selected according to the age and experience of the reader (e.g., texts should use a serif typeface, Grade I - 18-29 pts, Grade II - 16-21 pts, Grade III - 14-18 pts, Grade IV - 12-14 pts, Grade V and above - 11-12 pts. * Suitable line lengths are 26-50 ems (depending on the font size). * Suitable line spacing is 1-1.5 (for example 20/24 pts to 20/30 pts). * Suitable book sizes naturally depend very much on press size, but could be A4, A5, B5, Crown Quarto, for example.
 - 56 - ANNEX 8 INDONESIA BOOK AND READING DEVELOPMENT PROJECT BOOK CENTER 1. Background. During the 1970s and early-1980s, one of the results of a weak private sector publishing industry, combined with insufficiently coordinated government efforts, was poor availability of good quality textbooks to the education system. During the Integrated Textbook Project, the need was identified for a central body to execute operations relating to educational materials, and so the Book Center was founded under Presidential Decree (Keppres No. 4 of 1987), and its role elaborated and defined under the Decree of the Minister of Education and Culture (Kepmen No. 0274/0/1987). Under Article 2 of this decree, the Book Center is charged with the development and implementation of writing, translation, evaluation, selection, procurement and production, and also distribution of books on the basis of the policy defined by the Minister of Education and Culture. 2. Adjustment. The Book Center must re-emphasize its role as the government body responsible for setting educational materials standards, and expand its monitoring functions to ensure those standards are met and maintained. In terms of ensuring availability of sufficient numbers of quality textbooks, the Book Center must de- emphasize its role as a line production and distribution unit, and become increasingly involved in guiding and monitoring the private sector production and distribution. A carefully planned introduction of quality guidance and control functions must be implemented in parallel with the phasing out of line operations. The Book Center will carry out these quality control functions in support of the National Evaluation and Approval Comrnittee. 3. The proposed project would assist the Book Center to focus on its new functions as a service center, collaborating with the supporting publishers, and bodies such as the National Book Development Council (NBDC), public libraries, IKAPI, book reading promotion, NGOs, etc. instead of its present line production and distribution center functions. In general terns, the Book Center's objectives of coordinating book issues under the Ministry of Education and Culture (MOEC), and ensuring the provision of relevant books to the education sector, would remain unchanged. The methods and procedures by which it achieves these objectives would be adjusted to take account of the growing capacity of the private sector and the Government's wish to encourage this growth. During the project, the Book Center's activities would emphasize:
 - 57- ANNEX 8 (a) strengthening of the policy-making process and monitoring of policy implementation; (b) promotion of competition in the publishing industry; (c) facilitating private sector development; (d) making delivery of public services more effective; (e) making decentralization work; and (f) strengthening of copyright legislation and/or enforcement. Functions 4. Beginning from 1995/1996, the Book Center will focus its activities on, among others: (a) Evaluation of textbooks and teachers' guides published by the private sectors. (b) Monitoring textbooks distribution. (c) Evaluation of book quality. (d) Handling, organizing training and workshops regularly for: - writers - translators - editors - illustrators - distributors (e) Writing and distributing handbook for - textbook writing - textbook publishing - evaluation criteria - selection criteria - criteria of acceptable quality books (f) Setting up Book Information System. The Book Center, periodically, will collect, print and disseminate, books and price lists published in Indonesia, to the Book consumers, especially schools.
 - 58 - ANNEX 8 (g) Publish Indonesian Publishing Directory. Organization 5. The organizational structure of the Book Center will remain same as elaborated on in the Decree of the Minister of Education and Culture, May 8, 1987. The job description in the Sections, Subsections, Divisions, and Subdivisions was also clarified in the Ministerial Decree, February 12, 1988. The new functions due to the change in policy of the provision of textbooks would be accommodated and integrated into the existing organization. 6.  - 80- ANNEX 14 INDONESIA BOOK AND READING DEVELOPMENT PROJECT PROJECr MONITORING AND EVALUATION Introduction This plan is designed to monitor progress toward the following: * How well teachers, parents and administrators understand the objectives and procedures of the system. * How effectively books are distributed to schools. * How effectively teachers and students use them in classrooms. There is a compelling body of research evidence that suggests a positive qualitative effect on the achievement of children when good textbooks are available to each and every student in a classroom. It is further accepted that the availability of supplementary reading materials in houses and libraries is positively correlated with enhanced learning in school subjects. These positive relationships seem easily explained on three levels; their impact on student behavior, on teachers and parents and on the local school environment. As far as students are concerned, the presence and ready availability of attractive and interesting text-books and supplementary reading materials make it possible for self- motivated and interested students to advance their own learning. Even in the presence of poor or ineffective teaching, well designed books can become self-instructional tools and useful learning aids. Interested parents can use these same materials to encourage their children in developing good learning habits and motivating them to enrich and extend their school experiences. Well designed textbooks, and available library and "reading corner" materials, often can help even poorly trained teachers perform more effectively. Well structured lessons, adequate exercises for drill and practice and clear teachers' guides can be of enormous assistance in improving the performance of even the better trained and experienced teachers by suggesting new and improved pedagogical techniques. Finally, a school that is filled with good, attractive learning materials, with sufficient copies for each student and with a rich array of supplemental reading materials, is clearly a place dedicated to teaching and learning. The children and adults who occupy that building have access to the tools to accomplish a great deal.
 - 81- ANNEX 14 In order for these good effects to occur, three essential goals must be met: * Parents, teachers, school and regional administrators must understand and appreciate the objectives of the program and how the "system" functions. * Books and teachers' guide must be delivered to schools in a timely and efficient manner and in sufficient number so that each student has access to personal copies. * Books and teachers' guide must be in the hands of students and teachers and used appropriately as learning tools. Proposed Monitoring Process The proposed process would consist of two separate activities: ongoing monitoring from the regular school reports and annual visits to a randomly selected number of schools for on-site inspection. Indicator #1: How well teachers, parents and administrators understand the new system (a) Ongoing monitoring Add 1-5 questions to Information Center's Annual School Report concerning the new system. These questions would push teachers' and principals' understanding of how the new selection system is designed to function, how to order books, how to prepare parents and students for the new textbooks and library materials, etc. These reports are aggregated at the district and provincial levels and are sent to Jakarta (the Information Center) with about a 90 percent response rate. Using existing information on school characteristics, these findings can be reported annually by categories of schools and regions, e.g., rural vs. urban, private vs. public, Java vs. other, etc. (b) Visits to schools Select a sample of 120 SDs and 60 SLTPs from which national data could be estimated. Select and train interviewers/observers who would each visit several schools each year to: (a) Interview principals, teachers and parents, asking specific questions about the new textbooks, how well they are liked, if they seem to be helpful, problems with selection, ordering, deliveries, etc. (b) Interview a small number of students asking similar questions. (c) Observe and report activities of two or three classroom sessions involving textbooks and library materials.
 - 82- ANNEX 14 The interviewers' reports would be analyzed and reported by categories of schools (e.g., urban vs. rural, etc.) and reports of findings prepared. These findings would be compared to those reported in the School Reports and discrepancies noted. Visits to schools should be made unannounced and the activity should be done by an independent organization. For example universities or teacher training colleges could be contracted for this purpose. Indicator #2: How effectively books are distributed to schools (a) On-going Monitoring Each shipment of books to a Province, a district and a school, will include a simple self-addressed, postage-paid post-card which will provide the following information: * date books received; * condition upon arrival; * sufficient quantity or not. The returned cards would be sent directly to the Information Center where they would be collected and the data analyzed and reported by categories of schools and regions of the country, on a quarterly basis. (b) Visits to schools Interviewers described above, during their visits to sampled schools (120 SDs and 120 SLTPs) would ask teachers and principals a small number of questions about deliveries, inspect damaged books and report findings. indicator #3: How effectively students use their textbooks and the reading materials (a) Annual reporting Add 1-5 questions to Information Center's Annual School Report, concering teachers' and school principals' perceptions of the appropriateness and effectiveness of student usage of textbooks. Other questions would probe sufficiency of quantities and impressions of positive or negative effects. Resources will have to be provided to the Information Center to extract these data from the School Reports, analyze the responses and to report the findings according to categories of schools and regions of the country. (b) Visits to schools Interviewers described earlier, during their visits to sampled SDs and SLTPs, will observe students and teachers during classes using textbooks.
 - 83- ANNEX 14 During these observations, they will complete standardized observation check-lists. In addition, they will interview teachers and students about the impact of text books on the leaming environment of the classroom. These reports will be analyzed and findings will be reported by categories of schools and regions of the country. Mid-level findings may be used to alter or supplement project activities. Fnal findings will describe how well objectives have been met.

doc.abstracts: The Book and Reading Development Project will aim at improving the quality of basic education by addressing critical factors affecting both the supply of, and demand of, textbooks. This will be achieved through establishing government policies, regulations, procedures, and practices related to school books, and making textbooks available in classrooms in sufficient quantity and in a sustainable way. Specifically, the project will support: 1) provision of textbooks in all required subjects, for all children in primary (SD) and junior secondary (SLTP) schools, public and private, giving priority attention to poor children; 2) procurement of the SLTP textbooks from private publishers and Balai Pustaka, through a transparent and rigorous evaluation and approval process, with the objective of achieving a high quality in the books; 3) greater involvement at the provincial level, through implementing the procurement process for SLTP textbooks at the Kanwil level; 4) giving help to teachers in how to use the books better in the classroom; and 5) the promotion of reading, especially for children.
